text: France was represented by Marie Myriam, with the song '"L'oiseau et l'enfant", at the 1977 Eurovision Song Contest, which took place on 7 May in London. "L'oiseau et l'enfant" went on to bring France a fifth Eurovision victory, a record at the time. == Before Eurovision == === National final === Following the French success in 1976 with a song chosen through a national final, broadcaster TF1 again opted for a public selection. ====Semi-finals==== Each semi-final contained seven songs, with the top three in each going forward to the final. The qualifiers were chosen by public televoting.National Finals database 1977 Semis ====Semi-final 1==== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center" ! colspan="5" |Semi-final 1 – 20 February 1977 |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Draw ! Artist ! Song ! Televote ! Place |- |1 | align="left" |Gilles Marchal | align="left" |"Le centre du monde" | 4,213 | 4 |- style="font-weight:bold;background:navajowhite;" |2 | align="left" |Delfine | align="left" |"Du côté de l'enfance" | 5,511 | 1 |- | 3 | align="left" |Joël Prévost | align="left" |"Pour oublier Barbara" | 3,918 | 6 |- style="font-weight:bold;background:navajowhite;" |4 | align="left" |Pierre Charby | align="left" |"Chacun sa chanson d'amour" | 4,722 | 3 |- |5 | align="left" |Patricia Lavilla | align="left" |"Vis ta vie" | 3,810 | 7 |- style="font-weight:bold;background:navajowhite;" |6 | align="left" |Colin Verdier | align="left" |"La vie tu sais" | 4,881 | 2 |- |7 | align="left" |Maxime Piolot | align="left" |"Il faut partir" | 4,036 | 5 |} ====Semi-final 2==== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text- align:center" ! colspan="5" |Semi-final 2 – 27 February 1977 |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Draw ! Artist ! Song ! Televote ! Place |- style="font- weight:bold;background:navajowhite;" | 1 | align="left" |Monique Pianéa | align="left" |"Je suis comme elle" | 5,001 | 2 |- style="font- weight:bold;background:navajowhite;" |2 | align="left" |Corinne Colbert | align="left" |"La poupée" | 4,879 | 3 |- |3 | align="left" |Elisabeth Jérôme | align="left" |"Dans les nuages" | 3,293 | 7 |- style="font- weight:bold;background:navajowhite;" |4 | align="left" |Marie Myriam | align="left" |"L'oiseau et l'enfant" | 7,164 | 1 |- |5 | align="left" |Millie | align="left" |"Un enfant peut-être" | 4,332 | 5 |- |6 | align="left" |Primevère | align="left" |"Dîtes-moi" | 4,489 | 4 |- |7 | align="left" |Arlène | align="left" |"Le cerf-volant" | 3,960 | 6 |} ====Final==== The final took place on 6 March 1977, hosted by Evelyn Leclercq, Patrick Sébastien and Yves Lecoq. The winner was chosen by public televoting.ESC National Finals database 1977 {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center" ! colspan="5" |Final – 6 March 1977 |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Draw ! Artist ! Song ! Televote ! Place |- |1 | align="left" |Pierre Charby | align="left" |"Chacun sa chanson d'amour" |3,562 |5 |- | 2 | align="left" |Colin Verdier | align="left" |"La vie tu sais" | 4,845 |4 |- style="font- weight:bold; background:gold;" |3 | align="left" |Marie Myriam | align="left" |"L'oiseau et l'enfant" |10,178 |1 |- |4 | align="left" |Delfine | align="left" |"Du côté de l'enfance" |6,066 |3 |- |5 | align="left" |Monique Pianéa | align="left" |"Je suis comme elle" |2,740 |6 |- |6 | align="left" |Corinne Colbert | align="left" |"La poupée" |7,565 |2 |} ==At Eurovision== On the night of the final Myriam performed last in the running order, following Belgium. Pre-contest betting had suggested that the winner was likely to be one from Belgium, Germany, Ireland or the United Kingdom, with the French song not registering as a potential victor. The United Kingdom took the early initiative in the voting and held the lead until just over half way through, when a late run of high marks to "L'oiseau et l'enfant" and a dip in form from its challengers saw France claim the victory with a final total of 136 points, 15 ahead of the United Kingdom in second place. Although in later years "L'oiseau et l'enfant" attained the status of a Eurovision classic, at the time it was considered a surprising and unexpected winner. France had taken only three maximum 12s (from Finland, Germany and Switzerland) against six for the United Kingdom and four for Ireland, but had scored more consistently across the board, being the only country to receive votes from every other national jury.ESC History - France 1977 ===Points awarded to France=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=5|Points awarded to France |- !width=20%|12 points !width=20%|10 points !width=20%|8 points !width=20%|7 points !width=20%|6 points |- | valign="top" | * * * | valign="top" | * * * * * | valign="top" | * | valign="top" | * * | valign="top" | * * |- !width=20%|5 points !width=20%|4 points !width=20%|3 points !width=20%|2 points !width=20%|1 point |- | valign="top" | * | valign="top" | * * | valign="top" | * | valign="top" | | valign="top" | |- |} ===Points awarded by France=== {| class="wikitable" |- |width=20% bgcolor="gold"|'|| |- |width=20% bgcolor="silver"|10 points|| |- |width=20% bgcolor="#CC9966"|8 points|| |- |width=20%|7 points|| |- |width=20%|6 points|| |- |width=20%|5 points|| |- |width=20%|4 points|| |- |width=20%|3 points|| |- |width=20%|2 points|| |- |width=20%|1 point|| |- |} ==See also== *France in the Eurovision Song Contest *Eurovision Song Contest 1977 ==References== Category:Countries in the Eurovision Song Contest 1977 Category:France in the Eurovision Song Contest Category:1977 in France
